section.title: Variables, Options, and Parameters
section.para: How often have you been confused about whether to tag something as a variable, as an option, as optional, or even as a literal? Happens to me all the time. Hopefully this will help. I need help too; I admit it. Feel free to volunteer thoughts.
It might be a good idea to start with a few definitions, or at least what will serve as definitions.

listitem.para: A symbolic name associated with a value and whose associated value may be changed (from Wikipedia. DocBook supports several tags that you can use for variables; I'll introduce them as needed.

An option for a software command (from ). This definition sounds somewhat restrictive, because options can apply to more than just software commands. Ultimately, however, I think all options find their way to a command, so let's leave it at that for now.

The Optional element indicates that a specified argument, option, or other text is optional. The precise meaning of "optional" varies according to the application or process begin documented. (From ) Note the difference between this and <option>.

This can be a bit of a pain. What it is depends on who you ask:
In computing a parameter is defined as "a reference or value that is passed to a function, procedure, subroutine, command, or program" (from which actually gets it from )
declares a parameter to be "A value or a symbolic reference to a value". It states that "A parameter identifies something passed from one part of a computer system to another."
As you can see, it's a bit painful. I try to avoid it.

has its own description of this tag, and it's not something that we use a lot. Actually we use it a lot more than we should, and usually incorrectly. I'm going to ignore it for now, except perhaps to offer examples of when NOT to use it.

section.title: Examples
section.para: Descriptions and definitions are all well and good, but sometimes a few sound examples go a long way.
